 Karp Lykov was an Old Believer, a member of a fundamentalist Russian Orthodox sect, worshiping in a style unchanged since the 17th century . Lykov's style of worship has been unchanged since 17th Century .
 Old Believers had been persecuted since the days of Peter the Great, and Lykov talked about it as though it had happened only yesterday . Lykov was prone to complain about a merchant who refused to make a gift of 26 poods of potatoes to the Old Believer .
 Things only got worse for the Lykov family when the atheist Bolsheviks took power . The Lykovs family had a history of political turmoil .
 Under the Soviets, isolated Old Believer communities that had fled to Siberia to escape persecution began to retreat ever further from civilization . The Old Believers were forced to retreat even further from society .
 During the purges of the 1930s, with Christianity itself under assault, a Communist patrol had shot Lykov's brother on the outskirts of their village while Lykov knelt working beside him . Lykov had knelt in front of his brother during the attack .
 There were only four Lykovs in the family when Karp died in 1936 . Karp and his wife Akulina were the only four children .
 They had retreated ever deeper into the taiga, building themselves a succession of crude dwelling places, until at last they had fetched up in this desolate spot .
 Two more children had been bom in the wild — Dmitry in 1940 and Agafia in 1943 — and neither of the youngest Lykov children had ever seen a human being who was not a member of their family .
 Agafia and Dmitry learned of their parents' stories from their parents . All that Agafia knew of the outside world they learned entirely from their stories .

 The Lykovs struggled to replace the few things they had brought into the taiga with them . Dependent solely on their own resources, they struggled to find a way to survive .
 Clothes patched and repatched until they fell apart, then replaced with hemp cloth grown from seed . Clothes were patched and re-searched until the fell apart .

 Since these could not be placed in a fire, it became far harder to cook . Since these can't be put in fire, they became more difficult to cook.

 Dmitry built up astonishing endurance, and could hunt barefoot in winter . Sometimes returning to the hut after several days, having slept in the open in 40 degrees of frost .
 More often than not, though, there was no meat, and their diet gradually became more monotonous .

 Isabella “Belle’ Boyd was accused of spying on the Union Army in 1862 . She was freed for lack of evidence .
 The seventeen-year-old girl had been sending information about Union troop movements to Major General “Stonewall” Jackson of the Confederate army .
 After the battle, a warrant was issued for Boyd’s arrest . obtained a safe-conduct pass from Union Brigadier General James Shields, the commander of the First Division, at the time .

 She was tall, slim, and athletic, with a mane of red hair and a flamboyant personality . The actress was tall and slim, slim and athletic .

 She came from one of the more prosperous families of Martinsburg, Virginia . Her personal possessions included a slave, several horses, and a wardrobe of expensive frocks .

 Sarah Doublet Forest is the site of one of the 17th century praying Indian villages . It has some very beautiful rural areas, such as one of many beautiful praying villages .
 Reverend John Eliot of Roxbury, Massachusetts began trying to convert local Indians to Christianity in 1640s .
 Eliot expected the villages to adopt Christianity and English way of life . Eliot expected their inhabitants to adopt not just Christianity but also a way of English life . The villages had native names, but Eliot expected them to adopt English values .
 Apparently hunting, gardening and a seasonally nomadic life were just too pagan . Apparently hunting and gardening were too pagan.
 The Indians lived in wooden houses, raised livestock, and farmed like their Puritan neighbors . Instead of living in wooden homes, they lived in a wooden house and raised livestock .
 Men and women cut their hair in the English fashion and discarded their traditional dress for wool clothes . The traditional dress was discarded in favour of wool clothing .
 It’s estimated that up to 20% of Massachusetts Indians eventually lived in these villages . Since no villages remain you can correctly surmise things didn't turn out well .
 In 1675 the other 80% of the native population rose up to oust the English from Massachusetts in the conflict called King Philip f s war . The English were ousted in 1675 .

 Professor Daichang Yang, a plant biotechnologist, and his colleagues set to work to develop a rice that could carry the albumin gene .
 HSA-yielding plants such as potatoes have been used for the last two decades, but they have been too high cost and low yield for commercial use . According to Nature News, HSA plants are too expensive and too low yield .
 Rice seeds, with their high protein content and high yields, are proving to be attractive carriers of the HSA gene . Rice seeds are proving a good carrier of the gene, according to experts .
 The two were chemically and physically identical . They were also similar when tested for medical efficacy and immune reactivity . The two tested the same for medical effectiveness and immune reactions .
 In rats with liver disease, both types of HSA proved equally effective in relieving symptoms associated with cirrhosis . HSA was found to be equally effective at relieving the symptoms of liver disease .
 Rats that were given rice-derived HSA showed no stronger immune reaction than animals that had been given the plasma-derived version .
 Yang is hoping to get permission for human trials within the next two years . Yang hopes the U.S. Food and Dmg Administration will grant permission to human trials .

 Cross pollination among rice varieties occurs less frequently than among some cultivars such as canola . Cross-pollination is less common than among canola varieties . Rice varieties are different varieties of rice varieties .
 The Rice Knowledge Bank maintains by the International Rice Research Institute suggests up to 5% of a rice crop can be cross pollinated through wind, insects, birds, snails and water . Up to five per cent of rice crops can be crossed pollinated by wind and insects .
 Given the biotech industry’s penchant for ignoring research that reveals numerous problems with genetically modified crops, enthusiasm for this new supply of HSA needs to be tempered with considerable caution .
 Carri Wilbanks Special for USA TODAY . Buckle up and enjoy “America’s Favorite Drive,” from Virginia to North Carolina .
 The scenic link between Shenandoah National Park and the Great Smoky Mountains National Park is a meandering drive that winds visitors slowly through the southern highlands of Appalachia .
 Visitors can stay overnight at one of the many quaint towns just a few miles off the parkway . There are several overnight options along the route .
 Peaks of Otter Lodge is located at Milepost 86 and is open from spring to fall . The lodge has a full-service restaurant and lounge, as well as 63 rooms .
 Julian Price Park is one of several campgrounds along the drive . If car camping is more your speed, reserve your spot at one of the park’s largest campgrounds .
 Campground is open from May 9 through the fall . It offers canoes, fish and hike among the hemlocks and hickory trees that shade the campground .
 Visitors should keep their north of eyes out for black bears, river otters, 31 salamander species and Pisgah even the occasional peregrine in North falcon .
 Explore the 19th-century farm buildings at the site near Milepost 5.8.8 . Stroll along the parkway to Humpback Rocks and explore 19th century farm buildings . Enjoy a short stroll to the area's Hump Back Rocks .
 Mabry Mill is a must-see destination and the perfect place for a post-hike picnic . Nearby, one of the most photographed buildings on the drive, is a favorite spot for a picnic .
 The Blue Ridge Parkway also offers a great opportunity to take in the dazzling autumn fall foliage . Rhododendrons and other wildflowers are blossoming in spring .
 The parkway also offers visitors true mountain culture including mountain music at a number of concerts throughout the year . Visitors can also enjoy hiking and bird watching .
 Bluegrass, mountain gospel music and flatfoot dancing opportunities abound along the drive . Mountain gospel music, flatfoot dance opportunities abound on the way .
 The Blue Ridge Music Center celebrates the music and musicians of the area . The center is located in the Blue Ridge area .
 It features an outdoor amphitheater and an indoor interpretive center/theater . The site is located in New York, New Jersey .

 Bodie Cemetery was established in 1877 and consists of three discrete burial areas within the perimeter fence . The Bodie cemetery is located in the Bodie area .
 The People's or Ward's Cemetery is located on the north end of the cemetery . The cemetery is located in the People’s Cemetery .
 The Freemason's or Masonic, and the Miner’s Union plots are on the south end of the park . The Freemasons or . Masonic, or . Freemasons, and . the Miner's Union plots, are located in the north .
 The last burial to take place in the cemetery was on August 14,1994 . Kenneth L McKeough, bom in Bodie in 1908, was interred in 1994 .
 Due to Bodie’s status as a landmark, there are only about a dozen citizens left who may be buried here . Due to the status of Bodie, only a handful of people are believed to have been buried there .
 High water table in this area caused the graves to fill with water, and in 1877 the cemetery was moved to its present location . The cemetery has been moved to the current location of the cemetery .

 Before the establishment of a cemetery at Bodie, the earliest burials took place 18 miles northeast of Bodie at Aurora in the early 1860's and at Bridgeport, located 12 miles southwest, established in the late 1850's .
 Nearly all the Chinese originally arrived in San Francisco and moved from camp to camp . They moved from San Francisco to Bodie from Virginia City . Nearly all of them originally moved from Virginia .
 The Chinese owned and operated many businesses, even in the main part of town . The Chinese had many businesses in the area, including many businesses .
 A few Chinese miners mined their own claims, which had been deserted by Euro-American miners . The claims were abandoned by the U.S. and China .
 Both the Chinese and EuroAmerican population began to decline as the economic downturn began in town . The Chinese and American population began declining as the downturn began .
 Early Chinese cemeteries were only marked by wooden headboards and inscribed with the name and often the location in China where the remains were to be sent for final burial . Early Chinese cemetery was only marked with wooden headboard and inscribed .
 It was the belief of the Chinese immigrants that the final resting-place of their dead must be in family plots in China .
 Burials in America were only temporary as the graves would be reopened after several years . The bones would be shipped back to the deceased's home village when financially possible . Burials would be re-opened after years and the bones shipped back when financially available .
 According to religious beliefs the spirit of the dead person remains near the body, requiring care and attention from the descendants . According to their religious beliefs it is necessary to keep the spirit alive in the body .
 The saints may be forgotten or rituals ineffective if the bones are not returned to the home village . The bones of the saints may not be returned to their home villages .
 Social customs were responsible for determining which of the EuroAmerican population could be buried within the main cemetery . Ethnic background of the individual was also a crucial factor in location of the burial .
 Racial prejudice required that the Chinese be buried on the slope above the west perimeter fence . The remains of several hundred Chinese were buried in the area .
 By 1870 approximately 11 thousand Chinese had died in the U.S. and the remains of over 6 thousand had been shipped home to China . Over 6 thousand of the remains were shipped home .

 This showed the cemetery never extended to that area as previously thought . This showed that the cemetery did not extend to that part of the cemetery . The cemetery was previously thought to have extended into that area .

 Gero Huetter said his 42-year-old patient, an American living in Berlin, had been infected with the AIDS virus for more than a decade . Huetter: The patient, who was not identified, was infected with AIDS virus more than decade .

 Huetter w ho is a hematologist, not an HIV specialist prepared to treat the patient’s leukemia with a bone marrow transplant . He said some people have a genetic mutation that seems to make them resistant to HIV infection .
 If the mutation, called Delta 32, is inherited from both parents, it prevents HD 7 from attaching itself to cells by blocking CCR5, a receptor . ”1 read it in 1996, coincidentally,” Huetter said .
 Roughly one in 1,000 Europeans and Americans hav e inherited the mutation from both parents . Huetter set out to find one such person among donors .
 The 61st person tested carried the proper mutation . Out of a pool of 80 suitable donors, the 61st carried the correct mutation .

 He was a son of Robert and Louise Robinson, and the family lived on the outskirts of Beaver Falls . He was born in Beaver Falls, Oregon .
 He swam the Beaver River in the summer, hung out with his playmates around the Morado section of Beaver Falls . He took dares, like a typical boy, and swam in the river .
 On June 18, 1919, he and several friends were heading for a swimming hole on the Beaver River . They came upon the Pittsburgh, Harmony, Butler and New Castle Railway Co. bridge spanning Wallace Run .

 The Dobhar-Chu easily traversed the intervening mountains and difficult terrain, eventually reaching the spot where the two men lay in ambush . The two men were ambushed by the border patrolmen .
 In some versions of the story, the Dobhar-Chu killed one of the unfortunate horses and, before it could visit the men’s remaining steed, Terence surprised it and stabbed it to death .

 It is located in Conwall cemetery, in the townland of Drummans, approximately 2-3 miles (3.8km) from the lake where she is said to have met her untimely death .
 The tombstone is about four and a half feet by 2ft , laid horizontally in the ground . It is about 4.5 ft by 2 ft, laid horizontally .

 There have been reports from Irish loughs of mysterious denizens that do not fit easily within the category of the familiar ‘horseeel’ of Connemara .
 One of these (possibly the last of its kind) spotted in Sraheen’s Lough, a small body of water on Achill Island in Co. Mayo .
 Sraheen’s lough (which also goes by the name of Glendarry lough) is circular and roughly 400ft in diameter . The circular lough is also known as Glendary lough .
 There are dense rhododendron bushes growing around most of the shoreline . The site is located on the western extremity of Europe and is a more windswept and isolated wilderness .
 Significant within the context of the legend is the lough’s proximity to Glenade Lough in County Leitrim . The legend is said to have occurred in the early 2000s .
 Achill is situated just off Co Mayo, which is the county immediately west of Counties Sligo and Leitrim . The DobharChu legend is still a part of daily life in Achill .
 Even in the 20th century, there was an oral tradition of water monsters in and around Sraheens Lough, with many sightings claimed in the 1930s .
 In 1968 the old stories took on an air of literal truth when a series of inexplicable events appeared to turn myth into reality . Such tales were remembered and retold by the older generation and used to frighten unruly children .

 No creatures resembling Dobhar-Chu of folklore, such as the Sraheens Lough monster, have been reported from Ireland since the events of 1968 .
 If there ever was a ‘real’ creature whether endemic to Achill Island or a transient visitor to Irish shores the changes wrought to the region’s delicately balanced ecosystem since the early 1970s may have been the final nail in its coffin .
 Tourists in search of isolated beauty spots, the increase in water sports and other recreations and the growth in population, traffic and pollution have all taken their toll on the area .
 Sea-lice and disease caused by faecal material from cultured salmonoid species can eventually filter into an already fragile ecosystem, potentially devastating natural stocks . The area’s fish-farming industry, too, may have impacted on the food chain .
 Any animal returning to once traditional sanctuaries would discover a wholly different environment today . The animal sanctuary is no longer a traditional sanctuary in America .

 If the creatures were merely visitors to Achill Island, then perhaps they sought sanctuary elsewhere, in another remote island habitat or coastal shoreline . The creatures are believed to be living on Achill island .
 Perhaps they travelled to a country farther north, towards the Arctic circle, or even westwards towards Iceland and Greenland to become incorporated into the folklore of those lands .

 The nine-year-old White House was the largest private residence in the United States . Some rooms were bare of furniture, while others held drab offices .
 Dolley Madison wanted to redecorate some of the barren spaces in the White House . She wanted to create rooms in which she could host gala social events . The White House has been redecorated to create more social spaces .
 Previous first ladies had avoided publicity and public events, but Dolley Madison loved a party . Previous first lady had a reputation for avoiding publicity .
 She believed that she could increase her husband’s popularity and help him push his political programs through Congress if she became the leading hostess in First Lady Dolley Madison . Dolley said she wanted to be a better hostess for her husband .
 She drew up plans to create an elegant dining room, a drawing room, and a parlor in the White House .
 The first lady’s proposed redecoration would cost more than her $25,000 annual salary . She discussed her plans with her husband, who was taken aback .
 He told her that she would have to figure out some way to raise the necessary money . He said she would need to find a way to pay for the hospitalization .
 The fifty-seven-year-old president, who was sixteen years older than his wife, did not share her enthusiasm for entertaining . The president is the president of the United States .
 He was the principal author of the U.S. Constitution, but he was too bashful to make small talk at parties . The Constitution was written in 1887 .
 James Madison was happiest at his desk among books and papers . Madison seemed nervous in social situations .
 Madison was a short man, five feet, four inches tall . Pale and thin, with a weak, boyish voice, Madison was short, pale and thin . Madison was the short man .
 Dolley Madison, who sometimes called her husband ‘the great little Madison,” thought that he ought to attend more parties in order to develop a public image as a cheerful, friendly man .
 As if trying to counterbalance her husband’s subdued demeanor, the first lady cultivated a flamboyant style .
 For parties, she liked to dress up in imported French dresses with daring necklines .
 The first lady was so warm and unpretentious that almost everyone who met her immediately liked her . Although her wardrobe raised some eyebrows, her manner was warm .
 The writer Washington Irving described her as “a buxom dame who has a smile and pleasant word for everyone” Dolley Madison decided to seek help from the United States Congress .
 She invited congressmen of both political parties to tea at the White House . When they arrived, she took them on tours of the building .
 She showed them the bare rooms, which she described as a national embarrassment . The bare rooms are a 'national embarrassment', she said .
 A majority of congressmen voted for repairs and furnishings at the White House . $12,000 was spent on repairs and $14,000 on furnishings .
 Dolley Madison hired Benjamin Latrobe, the noted architect, to help her choose furnishings . The architect helped her choose the furnishings of her new home .
 Latrobe spent $2,150 for three mirrors, $556.15 for new china, and $220.90 for silverware . Latrobe, Pennsylvania, spent $1,500 for mirrors, china and silverware for china .
 At the request of the first lady, he also spent $28 for a guitar and $458 for a piano . The first lady requested the purchase .
 He was dismayed when she insisted on buying some velvet curtains that he found too gaudy for the drawing room . The curtains were bought by his wife and he found them 'too expensive'
 With her new decor in place, Dolley Madison began holding “receptions’ every Wednesday at the White House . The White House has been hosting receptions every Wednesday .
 Slaves and servants served the guests French cuisine, fine wines, and plentiful liquor . Guests were served French cuisine and fine wines .
 Dolley Madison carefully introduced every new guest to her husband . James Madison usually stayed in a comer with a few close friends, intensely discussing political issues . Dolley and James Madison were married in 1864 .
 Celebrated writers and artists who attended the receptions usually seemed more eager to meet the first lady than the president . The first lady was invited to the White House to meet President Obama .
 Dolley Madison's real goal was to increase her husband’s popularity, rather than her own, she said . For several years, she seemed to be succeeding . Dolley's husband's popularity was at the center of her success .
 President Madison caused a controversy in America when he asked Congress to vote for a declaration of war against Great Britain in 1812 . Madison caused controversy in the summer of 1812 with a request for war against Britain .
 The British government, which was at war with France, had provoked the U.S. by seizing American merchant ships bound for French ports . Americans were forcibly conscripted into the British navy .
 Federalists preferred the British monarchy to the radical dictatorship of Napoleon Bonaparte . Federalists hated the idea of helping a French dictator to fight against liberty-loving Englishmen .
 After that, Dolley Madison’s parties began to be disrupted by shouted arguments between antiwar Federalists and pro-war Democrats . The parties were interrupted by shouts from antiwar Democrats and antiwar Republicans .
 The first lady restricted her own conversation to small talk and laughter . She kept everyone calm as possible .
 In an effort to encourage national unity, the first lady threw more parties than ever . But her husband’s political problems grew worse .
 The president called for fifty thousand volunteers to invade Canada, but only five thousand signed up . Congress refused to raise taxes for what the antiwar congressmen called “Mister Madison’s war”
 James Madison’s popularity fell further when his underfunded attempts to invade Canada failed disastrously . His underfunded invasion of Canada was the result of a failed invasion .
 Dolley Madison became alarmed in 1813 when she heard rumors that British sympathizers and spies in Washington, D.C., intended to set fire to the White House to avenge the burning of the Canadian Parliament buildings at York by American invaders .
 Dolley Madison began sleeping with a saber under her bed, so that she would be equipped to fight off any arsonists who might try to climb through her bedroom window . The Executive Mansion's redecorated Executive Mansion has been renovated .
 The United States Navy was too small to oppose the enemy ships, which landed an army of four thousand British regulars on the shore of the Patuxent River in Maryland .
 Dolley Madison was alarmed by the depth of hatred that antiwar Americans were expressing towards her husband . She was alarmed not only by the enemy advance, but also by the level of hatred expressed by Americans .
 American army of one thousand regulars, backed by several thousand ill-trained militiamen, marched from Washington to confront the British invaders . Nobody in Washington seemed to feel much confidence in the American army .
 President Madison felt that the troops needed some encouragement to cheer them up . President Madison wanted to cheer up the troops .
 On August 23 he told his wife that he felt it was necessary for him to address the troops in the field . He asked her if she would be afraid to stay alone at the White House that night that night .
 Her husband expressed confidence in the American army, but also showed her cases of secret documents that he did not want the British to see .
 He told her that, if she was forced to flee from the White House, she should be sure to take the documents with her .
 Dolley Madison received an alarming dispatch from her husband on August 24 . The couple's daughter was found dead at the scene of an apparent suicide .
 The first lady loaded the secret papers into trunks and had them carried to her carriage . She then loaded them into her carriage and left them in the trunk .
 She found that the trunks completely filled the carriage, leaving hardly any room for her personal possessions .
 Many of the city’s residents were fleeing with all their goods . She tried to hire a wagon, but none was available because many of them were fleeing . None of the residents was able to get a wagon because of the fleeing .
 Dolley Madison was secretly worried that her husband might be lynched by antiwar Federalists . She was worried that she might have been lynched . The Federalists were defeated in the war .
 She felt that her own popularity might protect him, so she felt that she was eager to join him . She said she felt her popularity might help him .

 Dragons are a prominent totem in Chinese culture, believed to dominate natural forces like wind and rain . Dragons are believed to be the most powerful dragons in China .
 On this day, they “raise their heads” with the sound of rumbling thunder, a sign of the coming rains that will revitalize the earth . The rain is a sign that the earth will soon be revitalizing .
 Around this time, the earth is bursting with life, grass and trees are beginning to sprout and formers are getting ready to till the fields .
 In ancient China, people would worship the dragon god beside a river or a lake, praying for the precious spring rains to nurture their crops . The dragon god is believed to have been worshipped in ancient China .
 Ancient China used a constellation system called Twenty Eight Mansions to measure the locations of the sun, moon and stars . The system was used to decide the season of the year and the seasons .
 One constellation, called “the Double Dragon of the East, was hidden all winter beneath the eastern horizon . One of the brightest stars in the world was called ‘The Double Dragon’s Double Dragon .
 The special foods usually eaten on this day include dragon’s scales, popcorn, soy beans, pig's head and pig’�s head .
 In Nanzhan in Shandong Province, this day was the first big celebration after Spring Festival, and occasion for their femous mule and horse feir .
 Even people from Inner Mongolia and Xinjiang would participate in the feir, herding their domestic animals in advance .
 It was believed that on this day the well was full of dragon eggs and that bringing them home would bless the collector with a year of fevorable weather and good harvest .

 An enormous, monstrous squid attempted to attack an Antarctic fishing vessel in the Ross Sea in April 2003 . Reports appeared in the media of the attack in the Antarctic .
 Mesonychoteuthis hamiltoni was armed with swivelling razor-sharp hooks on its tentacles . It had eyes the size of dinner plates, and was itself referred to as the colossal squid .
 Not too surprisingly, it was widely dismissed as just another fraudulent beast engendered by the imagination of some reporter .
 Mesonychoteuthis hamiltoni is a species of species that existed in the wild . It is thought to be the first species to be found in the world of this species .
 The colossal squid first came to scientific attention from remains retrieved from the stomachs of sperm whales . The only member of its genus, which was created in 1925 to accommodate it, is the colossal squid .
 Until this new specimen, a half-grown adult female was reported, only one complete postjuvenile specimen had been recorded caught at a depth of 2,500ft in the Antarctic in 1981 . It is nowadays known from a number of juveniles, but until now only one specimen has been
 New specimen was almost 20ft long, but could have grown to 40ft . It was feeding on Patagonian toothfishes caught on longlines set by the fishermen .
 Not everyone was happy with these media reports, however, and on the online cephalopod discussion list, CEPH-LIST, a number of discrepancies between media speculation and zoological reality .
 It is more likely that this species ambushes its prey by hanging motionless in the water, rather than being forcefully aggressive . The colossal squid is thought to have ambushed its prey .
 Other squid species, even including very small ones, also have them modified from tentacles .
 There is no inference drawn that these are designed for attacking humans, but merely that they are modifications for capturing certain types of prey . So there should be no inference . It is not intended to be used against humans .
 Richard Ellis personally discounts the possibility that the colossal squid is any more of a monster than the giant squid, or any more dangerous to humans . Ellis: "I don't believe the squid is a monster. It's not a monster."
 Even the claim that the Ross Sea specimen was only half-grown and might therefore have attained a much greater size had it lived is unsubstantiated . The claim that it might have reached a much larger size is not substantiated .
 During their later stages of development, squid mature rapidly . Almost all their energy is channelled into sperm and egg production, not into body size increase .
 Ross Sea individual could have become fully mature, mated, spawned, and died without gaining any additional size .
 The Ross Sea specimen of colossal squid was indeed a remarkable discovery, and well worth receiving attention .
 Feverfew is a composite plant growing in every hedgerow, with numerous, small, daisy-like heads of yellow flowers . The central yellow florets are arranged on a nearly flat receptacle, not conical as in the chamomiles .
 The stem is finely furrowed and hairy, about 2 feet high . The leaves alternate, downy with short hairs, or nearly smooth . The leaf-stalk is flattened above and convex beneath, flattened .
 Chamomile is not to be confounded with other wild chamomilelike allied species, which mostly have feathery leaves and somewhat large flowers . The stem also is upright, whereas that of the true garden Chammile is procumbent .
 The whole plant has a strong and bitter smell, and is particularly disliked by bees . The plant has been described as a 'bitter and bitter' plant .
 A double variety is cultivated in gardens for ornamental purposes, and its flower-heads are sometimes substituted for the double Chamomile . The double variety can be grown in many gardens .
 Country people have long been accustomed to make curative uses of this herb . The herb grows abundantly throughout England .
 Gerard tells us that it may be used both in drinks, and bound on the wrists is of singular virtue against the ague . Gerard says it may also be used in drinks and in the wrists .
 Feverfew is a perennial, and herbaceous in habit . Pyrethrum is derived from the Greek pur , in allusion to the hot taste of the root . Feverfew has a reputation for being herbaceous and perennial .
 Once planted it gives year after year an abundant supply of blossoms with only the merest degree of attention . When once planted, it gives . year after years an abundant . supply of . blossoms .
 Planting may be done in autumn, but the best time is about the end of April . The best time to plant in the UK should be in April, experts say .
 Any ordinary good soil is suitable, but better results are obtained when well-drained, and of a stiff, loamy character, enriched with good manure . Better results are found in the soil of a firm, hardy soil .
 The plants when first put out being small might be injured by hoeing . Weeding should be done by hand, the plants are small and should not be put out .
 To propagate by division , lift the plants in March, or whenever the roots are in an active condition, and divide them into three or five fairly large pieces .
 Cuttings should be made from the young shoots that start from the base of the plant, and should be taken with a heel of the old plant attached, which will greatly assist their rooting .
 The foliage must be shortened to about 3 inches, when the cuttings will be ready for insertion in a bed of light, sandy soil, in the open .
 For the latter pest, try peppering the plants with soot, ashes or lime . For the others use soot or ashes, lime or soot is used .

 The herb, bruised and heated, or fried with a little wine and oil, is employed as a warm external application for wind and colic .

 "Flight From the Reich: Refugee Jews, 1933-1946,” is our new book . We investigated the failure of the allies to respond to the refugee crisis triggered by Nazi persecution .

 No authentic portrait of him exists, but he was allegedly unattractive . He is said to have been an unattractive man . He was allegedly a member of a gang of criminals .
 He was also literate, clever, and charming, with a charismatic personality . He also had a charming personality, and was literate and clever .
 At first L’Ouverture and his slaves allied themselves with Spanish forces from the neighboring colony of Santo Domingo who hoped to seize Saint-Domingue from France . The French government in Paris formally abolished slavery in its colonies in 1794 .
 This abolition of slavery, a belated effect of the French Revolution, transformed the French government into a radical ally of the rebel slaves . The French government became an ally of rebel slaves in the fight against slavery .
 L’Ouverture abruptly switched sides, accepting a commission as a French general . In response, L'Ouvertsure switched sides and accepted a commission in France .
 He then turned on his former Spanish allies and drove them out of SaintDomingue . He then drove the country out of the island .
 L'Ouverture hoped to unify the war-tom colony, gain greater independence from France, and establish permanent racial equality throughout Saint-Domingue . L’Overture was founded by the French colonialists .
 The defeat of the Spanish forces, and a treaty between Spain and France that ceded Santo Domingo to France, did not end the fighting in Saint-Domingue, because the British allies of Spain attacked .

 Based on a design by James Hoge, the ""Municipal Traffic Control System" comprised four pairs of red and green lights that served as stop-and-go indicators, each mounted on a corner post and operated by a switch inside a control booth . Hoge received a patent
 This invention brought to an end a growing problem in the early days of automobiles, when pedestrians, bicycles, horses and streetcars all converged on the same roadways, the History Channel says .

 KARL SHUKER on scientific intransigence in the face of a mass of evidence . KARl Shuker on the importance of scientific evidence .
 The megapodes are renowned for eschewing the tried and trusted method in favour of much more remarkable and ingenious versions . Most birds sit on them, thereby harnessing their own body heat to make their eggs .
 Some, for example, erect huge mounds composed of dead plant material, inside which they deposit their eggs, and allow the heat generated internally by the rotting vegetation to incubate them . Others erect mounds made of dead plants and allow their eggs to be incubated inside .
 Today, the megapodes are notable avian celebrities, with their extraordinary modes of incubation faithfully documented in ornithological publications worldwide . Today, therefore, they are notable birds of the night .
 For over three centuries, all reports of this most famous facet of megapode lifestyle were vigorously discounted by scientists as fanciful travellers’ tales with no basis in reality . Yet these same publications invariably neglect to mention that for over three hundred centuries, this was discounted .
 The history behind the formal scientific verification of these birds’ idiosyncratic incubation is a classic, compelling, yet nowadays all-but-forgotten example of a long-running zoological controversy .
 The chickensized bird laid eggs as large as a duck’s in the Philippines . Instead of hatching them itself, it chose to bury them in the sand, leaving them to be hatched by the sun's heat .
 Pigafetta’s egg-burying bird was dismissed in no uncertain terms by those selfsame authorities as arrant poppycock . In an age when mermaids, unicorns and other wholly imaginary creatures were still widely accepted by naturalists as factual fauna .
 Nieremberg did not record the creature's provenance, but that omission was remedied in 1651 via the publication of Francisco Hernandez’s Historia Avium Novae Hispaniae . The curious creature was found in the 16th century .
 Hernandez corrected Nieremberg’s ‘daie’ to daic, and his ‘tapun’to tapum, as well as revealing that this bird inhabited the Philippines . Hernandez corrected the 'daie' to 'daic' and 'tapun
 During 1673, the Dominican missionary Navarrete returned to Megapodes were discounted as travellers’ tales with no reality Europe after spending a considerable time in the Philippines . The Dominican missionary was discounted as a traveller’ tale with no real Europe .
 Many of the Malay Archipelago islands boasted a very unusual bird known locally as the tabon . In a lengthy account entitled A Collection of Voyages and Travels, he recorded that many of the . Malay . islands boasted . a very . unusual bird called locally as a tab
 After excavating great holes in the sand into which it deposited its eggs, it filled the holes up again, in order for the hot sand and sun to hatch the eggs . The eggs were deposited into the sand and then filled back in order to hatch .
 In 1699, Gemelli Careri provided comparable details regarding the Philippine jungle fowl, which he termed the tavon . Additional data, drawn from his avifaunal observations on Luzon, was presented in 1703 by Camelli .
 In view of such close correspondence between reports originating for the most part from wholly independent eyewitnesses and spanning two centuries, one might have expected that the jungle fowl’s internment of its eggs for hatching purposes would thereafter have been accepted as a fully verified ornithological fact
 Buffon and many other leading naturalists continued to disparage and reject totally all claims that birds could behave in such an overtly reptilian manner .
 The matter remained unresolved for another century, until attention switched from the jungle fowl’s Philippine representatives to those inhabiting Australia .
 In Australia the aboriginals insisted that this diminutive bird was actually the architect responsible for all manner of immense mound-like structures . It is widely distributed across much of northern Queensland and Northern Territory .
 Mounds hewn into the sides by the bird contained its eggs, experts say . They said that deep, concealed holes hewn in the mounds’ sides contained eggs . The mounds served as giant incubators, experts said .
 When the first Western settlers in Australia had encountered these incongruous edifices, some measuring up to 30ft long and 5ft high, they had taken them to be ancient burial mounds by the aboriginals .
 Other smaller mounds were deemed by them to be mud-castles built by native mothers to amuse their children .
 The fact that the aboriginals themselves vehemently denied all of this was ignored not only by the settlers but by Western scientists . Western scientists too, thereby rejecting the claims of a people whose knowledge of this island continent stretched back many millennia .
 English naturalist John Gilbert (assistant to famed ornithological painter John Gould) arrived in autumn 1839 at Port Essington, Northern Territory . He resolved to conclude this heated conflict once and for all .
 He would accompany a knowledgeable aboriginal to a little-known area of Port Essington called Knocker’s Bay, undisturbed by Westerners . The native people asserted that a number of jungle fowl could be found .
 The search for the remains of the mounds is ongoing in the area around the world's largest cemetery .
 Reaching the bay in November 1839, almost immediately they came upon a mound of sand and shells, incorporating a slight mixture of black soil too, and resting on a sandy beach just a few feet above the high water mark .
 5ft tall, with a circumference of 25ft and conical in shape, the mound was profusely festooned with large yellow hibiscus blooms . Standing roughly fiveft tall with a diameter of around 25ft, it was a conical mound of conical
 Gilbert scrambled up the mound’s sides to seek its alleged hidden holes and any eggs that might contain, but he failed to do so . Encouraged by this, Gilbert duly scrambled .
 There were no signs to suggest that any adult birds had been there for quite some while . However, his companion was unconcerned, pointing out that there were no sign of adult birds .
 Gilbert’s searches were not entirely in vain; on one side of the mound he spotted a tunnel-like shaft about 2ft deep, which proved to contain a jungle fowl chick, lying on some dry leaves .
 As it was only a few days old, presumably it had indeed hatched inside the tunnel . Gilbert could not be absolutely sure of this, but he said it must have hatched inside .
 The chick exhibited a remarkably advanced degree of development, with a well-formed, extensively-feathered body, plus the ability to mn and fly .
 Gilbert was unable to stay any longer at Knocker’s Bay . By 1840 he had returned and this time his quest met with success . Gilbert returned to Knocker's Bay in February 1840 .
 After selecting a likely-looking mound inside which to find eggs, his native companion dug down six times in succession to a depth of at least 6ft— 7ft without finding eggs .
 On the seventh attempt, he successfully retrieved one egg, followed after two or three more attempts by a second . The egg was retrieved by a team of scientists at the University of Cambridge .
 We now know that an average clutch contains about 15 eggs . One egg is laid and buried each day, within its own separate hole, until the entire clutch has been deposited .
 Gilbert also discovered that mounds constructed in darker, cooler localities, protected from the sun’s rays, are largely composed of plant material and rely principally upon the heat released by decomposition for egg incubation .
 Some scientists have opined that certain of the sand-and-shell mounds at Weipa, on Queensland’s Cape York Peninsula, are not bird-built . Yet even today, mystery still surrounds the mound-building megapodes .
 It is said that history never repeats itself, but in the case of the Australian jungle fowl, it currently seems to be running backwards from tumulus to incubator to tumulus again . The Australian fowl is said to have been in incubator and incubator incubator .

 One did not need super sensitivity, however, to feel uncomfortable in the third bedroom of this house . The house was decorated with flowers and flowers .
 CNN.com will feature a photo of a room in a room filled with light bulbs . The room is filled with people who have never seen a room like this .
 More mundanely, it had a bare, gritty floor, old wallpaper peeling in places, and a sash window with net curtain . It was a bare and gritty floor and old wallpaper was peeling .
 It felt cold as one would expect, but not just ordinarily cold as on any November evening . The weather was unusually cold, but it felt like it was cold again, even though it was chilly .
 "Here I found a bone-deep chill as though even its essence had been sucked away," says author .
 "I've experienced similar chill in other haunted places and it's always profoundly unpleasant," says author . "It's always profound unpleasant. It's the same thing I've experienced in haunted places," she says .
 We continued our tour of the house, which apart from that third bedroom felt normal enough . At the end, I told the Becketts I would like to spend some time there and conduct tests .
 A week later the family went to stay for a few days with Mrs Beckett's mother . During that time they allowed me and three colleagues to move in . The family then went to live with her mother's mother in her home .
 Arthur Latham, Ross Price and Martin Hodgkiss spent three nights and two full days in the house . They were all accompanied by the team who had accompanied him on previous investigations .
 We took regular temperature readings in the rooms and monitored four tape recorders . We also set up a movement-sensitive camera in the third bedroom .
 In addition Arthur, our electronics expert, installed a range of equipment to test atmospheric pressure, shifts in the house structure, and sensors to detect movement on the stairs .
 We of course experienced all the usual noises creaks, raps, bangings to be expected in any house, whatever age .
 We could also hear the television sets in both adjoining houses . At times it seemed the families had regiments of children running riot .
 On our first night I took up position at the top of the stairs on the landing, Ross in the boys' bedroom and Martin on the threshold of the third bedroom . Arthur remained in the lounge monitoring our equipment, while Ross remained on the floor .
 In each room we had a low-power bulb burning, and all interior doors were open . All interior doors and light bulbs were open in each room, with no lights on .
 At 2.13am we clearly heard the distinctive squeaking sound of the door at the bottom of the stairs opening . Almost immediately footsteps began slowly ascending . At 2:13am, the door opened and footsteps began to slowly ascend .
 Being on the landing, I could see both the staircase, which was in deep shadow but empty, and the open door . The staircase is in shadow, but empty but empty .
 Perhaps the most interesting, and certainly most sinister, phenomenon occurred in that room . The most interesting thing happened was that the room was filled with light and sound .
 The sound, like someone dragging their feet across the uncarpeted floor, continued for seven minutes . Nothing could be seen at the scene of the incident .
 I joined Martin at the doorway and immediately noticed the extreme chill billowing out, and a sense of menace that had the hairs on our necks bristling . The extreme chill was billowing from the doorway, and it was the chill of the night .
 We were satisfied that the noise came from the room itself and not from the adjoining houses, nor from the walls or loft . We were happy to find out that no noise was caused by the noise of the room .
 Arthur reported that his equipment had indicated sounds being recorded in the third bedroom at the time Martin and I specified . With the dawn we compared notes, and Arthur reported the sounds were being recorded . Martin and Arthur were able to find each other in the room .
 It emerged deep, hoarse and muffled, and it said just one word, repeated three times . It emerged from the mouth of a man whose voice was hoarse . The man's voice was so muffled that it could barely be heard .
 Ross, Martin and I switched positions for the second night, and again for the third night . Ross and Martin switched positions on the night of the first night, the third .
 There were more footsteps on the staircase on the second night, at 3.19am, and again the tape recorder picked up a voice in the third bedroom . This time we couldn't even guess at the word or words, but this time we could not .
 Albert and Dora Owen had lived in the house since at least the 1920s . There had never been any suggestion of strange occurrences at the house .
 I managed to trace Mr and Mrs Owen's son Derek, who now lived in North Wales, and from him he heard a slightly different story . Mr Owen's wife and Mr Owen Owen's daughter now live in Wales .
 He had grown up in the house and had occupied the third bedroom as a boy . He always felt uncomfortable there and suffered constant nightmares . He suffered nightmares until moving into another room .
 Derek said his mother had sometimes spoken of feeling uncomfortable in the upstairs rooms . 'She used to say somebody seemed to be hovering over her,' Derek said .
 He also told me of a rumour that someone had once hanged themselves in the house . I was unable to verify this either through the landlord or through library records .
 "There were at least two presences in the house, one benign and the other most definitely not," says Alan Beckett .
 I thought it was possible that the footsteps on the stairs were caused by the ghost of Albert Owen . I thought that though they might find this phenomenon disconcerting, it would not harm them and was likely in time to disappear .
 I could not say the same for the presence in the third bedroom, however, however .

 The priest and two colleagues spent five hours at the house in mid-December . They reported a deep sense of evil in the third bedroom and, to a lesser extent, elsewhere .
 They were convinced, however, that their exorcism had succeeded and that the presences had been banished . The exorcism was not the first attempt to exorcise the spirits .

 KARL SHUKER returns to the subject of winged cats now known to be sufferers from feline cutaneous asthenia . He unearths some additional cases both old and new .
 Wiveliscombe kitten of 1899, the black-and-white individual on show at Oxford Zoo during the 1930s, and the Manchester builder’s yard moggy publicised during the 1970s, are among my favourite fortean creatures .
 Cats exhibiting FCA have abnormally flexible , fragile skin, which if rubbed or stroked can stretch out into long furry wing-like extensions along their shoulders, back or haunches . If merely rubbed, stroked, cats can stretch their furrows into long furrows . Cats exhibiting
 Because these extensions contain musculature, they can even be raised up and down a little, heightening their superficial resemblance to wings . And because they contain musmusature, the extensions can even raise up a little .
 If stretched too much, these extensions peel off, but without any bleeding, thus giving the impression that the ‘wings’ have moulted .
 In recent years, little new material concerning winged cats has been published, but I have continued collecting data concerning these purring paradoxes .
 Here is a long-overdue update, which contains a number of previously unpublished cases, or cases hitherto unpublicised in the literature .

 Cast iron pillar is 23ft high and weighs more than six tonnes . The cast iron pillar, which has never corroded, is 23 ft high . It is the largest in the world and has never been corroded .
 A thin layer of 'misawite' (iron hydrogen phosphate hydrate) has protected the monument, preventing the iron from reacting with oxygen to form rust . Theories explaining the mysterious properties of the pillar are legion .
 A film formed over the pillar within three years of its erection and has been growing ever since . After 1,600 years the layer is just onetwentieth of a millimetre thick .
 The film was formed by high amounts of phosphorous in the iron as much as one per cent against less than 0.05 per cent in modern iron . A report published in the journal Current Science suggests the film formed by phosphorous .

 The gas molecules are collected in a bell jar and bombarded with calibrated laser beams, which makes them vibrate . They are then bombarded by laser beams to vibrate with a vibrator .

 It should not be surprising that humans exhibit a fear of serpentine water images given the terror which many exhibit towards snakes .
 For millions of years our ancestors were grubbing about in tropical lands in search of small edible creatures from termites to toads where venomous snakes also dwelled . Our ancestors were searching tropical lands for small edible animals .
 Any hominid who grabbed such a snake for a meal would have been bitten in defense and so eliminated from the family tree . Hominid would have bitten the reptile in defense .
 Those who fearfully avoided snakes were the ones who survived to pass their loathing on to future generations, including today's often-cryptozoologist humans . Those who avoided snakes, on the other hand, were those who survived .
 Humans and other creatures exhibit a seemingly morbid fascination directed towards threatening situations such as wildfires, a charging bull, or a falling tree . Such riveting attention keeps them on guard in case the threat spreads .
 It is possible that such trepidation of potentially venomous snakes, operating at a subliminal level below overt fear, may be the source of these lake monster legends .

 U.S. Geological Survey scientists discovered that trees are being killed by high concentrations of C0 2 gas in the soil . C02 gas is found to be in high concentration in soil .
 The seepage of C0 2 gas from below Mammoth Mountain and the continued occurrence of local earthquakes are signs of the ongoing geologic unrest in the area .
 Leaves of plants produce oxygen from C0 2 during photosynthesis, but roots need to absorb 0 2 directly . Roots absorb oxygen directly from the roots of plants . Leaves produce C02 from photosynthesis but roots absorb it directly .
 The high C0 2 concentrations in the soil on Mammoth Mountain are killing trees by denying their roots 0 2 and by interfering with nutrient uptake . Trees are also being denied nutrients by denying roots and blocking nutrient uptake in soil .
 When C0 2 from soil leaves the ground, it normally mixes with the air and dissipates rapidly . C02 from soil usually mixes with air and dies rapidly .
 C0 2 is heavier than air, but it can collect at high concentrations in the lower parts of depressions and enclosures . It can collect in high concentrations, posing a potential danger to people, experts say .
 Breathing air with more than 30% C0 2 can very quickly cause unconsciousness and death . Breathing water with over 30% of C02 can quickly kill . Breathalysants can also kill if they inhale enough of the air to breathe .
 Poor ventilated areas above and below ground can be dangerous in areas of C0 2 seepage . C02 seepages can be found in areas with poor ventilation .
 Where thick snowpacks accumulate in winter, the C0 2 can be trapped within and beneath the snow . The C02 2 can also be trapped in thick snowpack .

 C0 2 gas is heavier than air and can collect in snowbanks, depressions, and poorly ventilated enclosures, such as cabins and tents, posing a potential danger to people . When it leaks from the soil, it can collect .

 High C0 2 concentrations in the soil kill plants by denying their roots 0 2 and by interfering with nutrient uptake . High C 0 2 concentrations also kill plants .

 This value varies on both short (days to weeks) and long time scales because of changes in atmospheric conditions and in the rate at which gas is being released from beneath the volcano .
 Carbonisotopic analyses of the annual growth rings in trees near the margins of the treekill areas imply that the gas-emission rate reached a peak in 1991, and then declined . The rate has been relatively stable since about 1996 .
 C0 2 and other volcanic gases, like helium, seeping from Mammoth Mountain appear to be leaking from a large reservoir of gas . The reservoir is supplied by repeated intrusions of magma .
 Tree-ring evidence from near springs on the mountain's flanks shows some C0 2 gas was leaking before 1989 and dissolving in the ground-water system .
 It is likely that the latest intrusion of magma opened deep fractures, increasing the rate of gas seepage . The latest intrusion is likely to open deep fractures in the region, say experts .
 The continuing occurrence of small earthquakes and C0 7 seepage beneath Mammoth Mountain are only two of the many signs of volcanic unrest in the area .

 They exist on the floor of the Nazca desert in a southwestern part of Peru, near the ocean . They are found on the bottom of the desert in the southwest of Peru .
 Natural objects include animals such as birds, camelids, or snakes . The natural objects include birds, snakeids and snakes .
 The lines were created by removing ironoxide coated pellets to a depth of four to six inches . That left the lighter sand below in stark contrast to the surrounding sand below .
 In fact, they can be seen quite easily when standing on nearby mountains or hills .
 The newly revealed figures are of a snake, a bird, a camelid (perhaps a llama) and some zig-zag lines . The figures were discovered by de la Torre .
 They are actually on some hills in the El Ingenio Valley and Pampas de Jumana near the desert floor . The hills are actually in some hills and are on the edge of some of the desert floors .
 The reason for the creation of the geoglyphs is still uncertain, though a host of possible explanations have been offered, many centered around religion and or water .
 All of the figures are believed to have been created using a single line that never crosses itself . Similar to how a picture might be drawn with a pencil, never lifting it from the paper .
 Archeologists have found evidence of wooden stakes used to help create the images . It has also been noted that many of the images depicted by geoglyphs also appear on pottery made by people over the same period .

 ‘sky at night’ means sunset in the west, and “sky in the morning” means sunrise in the east . In Britain and the northwestern U.S. the prevailing winds come from the west .
 At sunset if the sky is sunny and bright in the west, the clear, moisturefree air between the observer and the horizon is scattering predominantly red light .
 The weather will remain dry for many hours whilst the wind moves towards the east . This means the weather will stay dry for the next few hours . The wind will continue to move towards the north of the coast .
 At sunrise, however, when the red sky is in the east, there is no guarantee that these conditions will remain for long . The prevailing winds will soon blow the clear air away, and the next weather front carrying rain clouds will likely blow in from the west .
 Red sky in the morning is not as reliable a shepherd's warning as red sky at night . But rain clouds might not come in from the west, so red sky is not reliable .

 The phrase ‘ontogeny recapitulates phytogeny’ was, during the 19th century, one of the main arguments of scientific racism in the Western world . It was used as an argument for scientific racism .
 Individuals of a species do seem to develop characteristics associated with other animals, such as other animals . Individuals seem to have a tendency to mimic other animals in their species .
 Human embryos, for instance, develop gill slits on their necks, a three-chambered heart (which expands to four chambers) and a tail . Human embryos also develop gills slits, a heart, a tail, and a heart .
 These characteristics seemed to prove the 19th-century idea that evolution was a ladder of progress with humans at the top of the ladder . These characteristics proved to prove that evolution .
 Recapitulation theory even placed human races in a biologically determined hierarchy . The theory was based on race relations between humans and other races .
 Some races were ranked superior to others; white Western Europeans and Americans were placed on top . White Western Europeans were placed top .
 Scientists theorized that other human races could be understood by studying the behavior of white children . The behavior of other races could also be studied by white children, scientists say .
 20th-century biologists replaced the model of evolution as a ladder with one of a manybranched bush . They no longer had a place for recapitulation theory and it was discredited .

 The Ouija was invented as an oracle game in 1892 by Elija J Bond . Elija Bond invented the Ouija as a game of oracle oracle games . Bond invented Elija in the 1892 .
 The name is derived from the French and German words for ""yes,"" oui and ja. The name means "yes" or "Ja" in German and French .
 The user asks a question, places fingertips on the pointer and then allows the pointer to spell out the answer . The question is answered by the user using the pointer .
 Most likely, the user moves the platform subconsciously without realizing it, but many people feel the movements are directed by discamate beings and spirits of the dead .
 Ouija enjoyed great popularity due to interest in Spiritualism and to the thousands of bereaved people after World War I who tried to find ways to communicate with their loved ones who had been killed in the war . Shortly after its invention, Ouija became popular .
 Since then, its popularity often has coincided with popular interest in the occult .
 Since 1966 the Ouija has been marketed by the Parker Brothers game company of Beverly, Massachusetts . Parker Brothers states that it is a game for entertainment purposes . Ouija is marketed by Parker Brothers .
 In experimenting with the Ouija, some users find that they can do automatic writing with it . The Ouija can be used to communicate with a Ouija .
 Skeptics contend that such writings really come from the user's own subconscious . Skeptic says such writings come from a user's subconscious .
 Others theorize Ouija users may have natural mediumistic abilities . Ouija has enabled them to contact discamate beings or spirits of the dead, some say .
 Some critics contend that such contact is inherently dangerous, and that any beings who communicate through such a device are likely to be demonic and attempt to possess the user .
 Ouija use in automatic writing and alleged communication with spirits of the dead have been benign, even productive, in nature . Many cases of Ouija using automatic writing have been found to be benign, or even productive .

 Seth allegedly used Roberts' vocal cords to speak . The communication then progressed to direct automatic writing with a pen and then trance mediumship . Seth allegedly wrote with Roberts' voice using his own vocal cords in trance .

 Betty began using automatic writing and then trance mediumship, in which the spirits allegedly used her own vocal cords . After initial contact was made through the Ouija, Betty then used automatic writing .

 In Bahasa Jawa is also called pasaran hari, or the “market day” cycle . This system structures time around trade and commerce, and in Jawa it is also known as pasaran .

 The General Patton Memoriil Museum in Chiriaco Summit just off Interstate 10 near lesert Center, about 30 miles :ast of Indio — is home to nunerous artifacts collected from he nearby training grounds .
 World War II-era photos and WWII-era news clips cover the walls of the building .
 The collection includes artifacts from World War I to the present war on terror . Artifacts from other wars are also included in the collection . The collection also includes World War II artifacts .
 The history of the General Patton Memorial Museum begins with the Chiriaco family . The museum was founded by the family of General Patton soldiers .
 Joe Chiriaco came west from Alabama to see the Crimson Tide play Stanford in the Rose Bowl in Pasadena in 1927 . He came west in 1927 from his home state of Alabama to watch the game .
 The game ended in a 7-7 tie, the last Rose Bowl game to finish in a draw . Incidentally, it was the last game to end in a tie . The Rose Bowl was held in Pasadena, California, in 1964 .
 Chiriaco never returned to Alabama, opting to remain in Southern California . He found a job as a surveyor with the Los Angeles Bureau of Water and Power .
 He made his first trek to the desert when his work brought him to an area known as Shaver Summit . The name was changed to Chiriaco Summit in 1958 when a rural branch of the United States Post Office was opened .
 With rumors of a new paved road between Indio and Phoenix, Joe began constructing a building, and on Aug., 1933, he opened a gas station and general store .
 The new two-lane blacktop, United States 60, opened in front of Shaver Summit . That same day, the new two lane blacktop opened, passing through the area .
 Joe married his wife, Ruth, in 1934, and the couple worked 18hour days providing service to the traveling public . Joe and Ruth worked 18 hours a day providing 18 hours of service . Joe married in 1934 .
 Patton established the Desert Training Center, with its headquarters at Camp Young, adjacent to Shaver’s Summit . The only place of its kind ‘on limits” to the soldiers for many miles was Camp Young .
 The availability of water to the Desert Training Center was one of the main reasons Patton selected the area and placed camps accordingly . Patton's camp camp is located in the desert area .
 The center is considered the largest military training facility in the history of military maneuvers . It stretches over 18,000 square miles of rugged desert terrain from Southern California into Arizona and Nevada .
 From 1942 to 1944, more than one million soldiers trained at the center, populated by thousands of tanks, trucks and selfpropelled artillery units . Thousands of tanks and artillery units were trained there .
 Almost all the facilities at the camp were non-permanent tent cities . Almost all of the facilities were tents, tents and tents .
 The museum was established next door to Joe Chiriaco’s original establishment, which is still in operation . Seventy years later, vestiges of the camp remain and mementos of its historic past are preserved .
 The museum was first conceptualized in 1985 by Margit Chiriaco Rusche and Leslie Cone of the Bureau of Land Management, the agency that manages the land upon which the training center existed .

 Dozens of passengers had to rock a train carriage back and forth to free a man whose leg was caught in the gap at a Perth station . The incident happened at the Perth station on Monday morning .
 Public Transport Authority spokesman David Hynes said the man was boarding the train into the city at Stirling Station on Wednesday morning when he stepped awkwardly, causing him to slip down the gap .
 The gap between the train and platform was less than five centimetres . He said it was an impressive feat because the gap between them was just 5cm .
 Passengers were asked to stand to the other side of the carriage to push the weight away from the man . But it was not enough to free him, Mr Hynes said .
 The man was lifted to safety by other passengers once the gap widened . He warned people to 'mind the gap' and not to stand near the doorways of trains .
 Paramedics treated the man but he was not badly injured and caught a later train . The man was treated by paramedics but was not seriously injured by the incident .

 Traditional Chinese astronomy operates under an entirely different system of stars and constellations than that recognized by the International Astronomical Union .
 As tong as 4,300 years ago, an astronomical officer was already regarded as an important position in a tribe . The position was already an important role in an important tribe .
 His duty was to observe and record the movements of celestial objects, and formulate a calendar to guide the daily lives of his people, especially their agricultural activities . He was born in China .
 The sky was divided into 3 1 regions, each consisting of a group of stars . As early as the Shang Dynasty (2070 B.C. 1600 B.A.C.), the sky was split into three 1 regions .
 The Three Enclosures formed the centerpiece of the northern night sky, and can be observed all year around . The Three enclosures are located in the Northern Hemisphere .
 Ancient Chinese thought of them as the residence and work place of the Jade Emperor and his ministers, as well as the busy downtown streets they governed . Surrounding these central three regions are the remaining 28 star clusters known as the TwentyEight Mansions .
 They were forther divided into four groups of seven, one for each of the four cardinal directions . The cardinal directions were divided into groups with seven cardinal directions each of them .
 The Four Symbols were used by ancient Chinese to represent the four main points of the compass . Collectively, they are known as the Four Symbol . They were used to symbolize the compass compass .

 Both belong to the region of the Black Tortoise, though they appeared under different names . Both were found in the same region, but they are believed to have been the same .

 The Salton Sea began with the formation of a great shallow depression, or basin, which modern explorers have called the Salton Sink . It is now the world's largest seater, and the most important part of the sea system .
 Several million years ago, a long arm of the Pacific Ocean extended from the Gulf of California to the present-day Imperial and Coachella valleys . The arm extended northwesterly through the Sacramento and San Joaquin valleys .
 Mountain ranges rose on either side of this great inland sea, and the whole area came up out of the water . Mountain ranges came up from the water, and mountain ranges rose from either side .
 Oyster beds in the San Felipe Mountains, on the west side of Imperial Valley, are located many hundred feet above present sea level . Oyster bed is located on west side side of the Imperial Valley .
 The area south of the San Gorgonio Pass sloped gradually down to the Gulf . Slowly the land in the central portion settled and the land settled .
 California’s Overlooked Treasure, in a 1995 issue of The Periscope, a publication of the Coachella Valley Historical Society, in Indio .
 The river deposited vast quantities of silt into the Gulf, creating a delta, from Yuma to the rampart of the Cocopah Mountains, that separated the region from the Pacific Ocean . The delta became a great salt water lake, covering almost 2,100 square miles .
 The depression was about one hundred miles in length by thirtyfive in width . It was one hundred and thirtyfive miles long by thirty-five in length .
 It’s unknown how long the ancient sea-bottom remained dry, but many thousands of years ago, the Colorado River proceeded to refill the dry basin . The Colorado River then filled the sea bottom with water .
 The river cut a channel to the Gulf through the eastern part of the delta plain . Then the river changed course, cutting a channel through the east . The river is now a national park in Louisiana .
 From 1824 to 1904, Colorado River flows flooded the Salton Basin no fewer than eight times . The Salton basin was flooded eight times between 1824 and 1904 .
 An 1840 flood created a salt lake three-quarters of a mile long and a halfmile wide . In 1891, another outpouring of Colorado River water created a lake 30 miles long, 10 miles wide .
 It is uncertain as to how many times water has filled the basin over the centuries but human intervention is responsible for inundating the basin only once . Human intervention has only inundated the basin once .
 In 1901, the California Development Company dug irrigation :y of overflow i the Colorado River to stop the water from flowing into the Salton Sink. canals from the Colorado river .
 Heavy silt loads, however, inhibited the flow of the river . New residents of the valley became worried about the silt .
 Engineers created a cut in the western bank of the Colorado to allow more water to reach the valley . This prompted the engineers to create the cut in order to save water from the Colorado .
 Heavy flood waters broke through the engineered canal in 1905, and nearly the entire volume of the Colorado River poured into the sink, unimpeded, for over 18 months .
 The raging river flooded thousands of acres of farmland and destroyed large portions of Calexico and Mexicali . Thousands of acres were flooded by the raging river .
 Approximately 11,000 acres of Torres Martinez Desert Cahuilla Indians tribal land was flooded . Approximately 11.000 acres were flooded . The land was covered by water .
 The Southern Pacific Railroad was forced to move its lines several times as the sea rapidly grew in size . The railroad had to move lines to accommodate the growing population of the sea .
 Four separate projects were started to try and stop the hemorrhaging river all ending in failure . Four separate attempts to stop the bleeding river have failed .
 The last trainloads of rock were dumped, cars and all, in a lastditch effort to quell the flow of the river . The last trains were dumped in an effort to stop the flow .
 On Feb., 1907, 2 million cubic feet of rock and $3 million later, Southern Pacific closed the breach . The river once again headed toward the Gulf of California .
 Agricultural drainage from new farms in Imperial Valley to the south kept water flowing into the newly christened Salton Sea . Agricultural drainage in the Imperial Valley keeps water flowing to the sea .

 Saved from the Titanic is a 1912 silent motion picture short starring Dorothy Gibson . Gibson survived the sinking of the RMS Titanic on April 15, 1912 . Gibson was an American film actress who survived .
 She had been one of around 28 people aboard the first lifeboat to be launched from Titanic . She was rescued about five and a half hours after leaving the ship .
 She co-wrote the script and played a fictionalized version of herself in the new film .
 The plot involves her recounting the story of the disaster to her fictional parents and fiance . The footage is interspersed by stock footage of icebergs, Titanic’s sister ship Olympic and the captain Edward Smith .
 To add to the film’s authenticity Gibson wore the same clothes as on the night of the disaster and rescue .
 It was the first film to be made about the disaster and premiered in the U.S. just 29 days after the ship sank .
 The film was released internationally and attracted large audiences and positive reviews . Some criticized it for commercializing the tragedy so soon after the tragedy .
 The last known prints of the film were destroyed in a studio fire in March 19 14 . It is now regarded as a lost film .
 Dorothy Gibson suffered a mental breakdown after completing the film . It is also the last film that Dorothy Gibson ever made, as she suffered from mental strain after completing it . The film was the last to be made by Dorothy Gibson .

 Salton Sea History Museum was established at the North Shore Beach & Yacht Club in May 2010 . These historic materials were at one time on public display at the thriving museum .
 The museum moved into the yacht club following a $3.5 million renovation of the Albert Freydesigned building . The 6,500-square-foot-foot, two-story facility was built by the renowned architect in 1959 .
 When the museum lost its place at the yacht club in June 2011, due to a dispute about the organization’s nonprofit status, it reopened in February 2012 at a bungalow at the Torres Martinez Desert Cahuilla Indians Wetlands property .

 The Salton Sea was created in 1905 when an irrigation channel off the Colorado River was breached and water flooded into the basin . An irrigation channel was breached in 1905 and the current sea formed in its current form .
 The water kept flowing until 1907, when engineers were finally able to stop it . The water was finally stopped by engineers in 1907 .
 Since then, the lake has been sustained largely by plentiful runoff from Imperial Valley farms . The lake has since been sustained mostly by plentiful runways .
 More water will be transferred to San Diego and cities in the Coachella Valley under the nation’s largest agriculture-to-urban water transfer . But that runoff has been decreasing and is set to decline dramatically after 2017 .

 Many invertebrates, such as insects, can produce offspring asexually, without ever having mated . Insects can also produce offspring without mating or mating . In insects, insects can also have offspring without mating .
 They usually do this by cloning themselves, producing genetically identical offspring . This is when they do so to produce genetically identical children .
 Among vertebrate animals, it remains a novelty, having been documented among less than 0. 1% of vertebrate species .
 In 2006, scientists discovered that two komodo dragons had produced eggs that developed without being fertilised by sperm . The process is called parthenogenesis .
 Captive female hammerhead sharks can reproduce without having sex . In 2007, other scientists found captive female sharks could also reproduce without sex .
 Not including genetic material from the father essentially having just a single biological parent reduces genetic diversity and makes it more difficult for organisms to adapt to, for example, changed environmental conditions or emergence of a new disease .

 Sex chromosomes are packages of DNA that drive the development of sexual characteristics . They essentially make animals genetically male or genetically female . Sex chromosomes make animals male or female .
 Humans have X or Y sex chromosomes; females have two X chromosomes and males have a combination of an X and a Y chromosome . Humans for example have X and Y chromosomes .
 snakes and many other reptiles have Z and W chromosomes . In place of X and Y, snakes have X and Z chromosomes . Reptile chromosomes are X chromosomes .
 The snakes inherited all their genetic material from their mother, as only females carry the W chromosome . This is further proof that the snakes inherit all their . genetic material .
 Baby snakes have inherited two copies of one half of their mother's chromosomes, including one W chromosome . That is because they have inherited one copy of one of the mother's W chromosomes . The baby snakes have also inherited a W chromosome from their mother .
 No vertebrate animal in which females carry the odd sex chromosome has ever been recorded naturally producing viable WW offspring via a virgin birth . More astonishing though, is that no vertebrate animals in which the females carry odd sex chromosomes have ever produced viable offspring .
 All known examples of parthenogenesis are male, carrying a ZZ chromosomal arrangement . In such species, all known examples are male with ZZ chromosomes .
