 T he Irish have always had a way with death .
 Few other nations can measure up to the Irish in the number and variety of folklore, traditions, and stories about death and dying .
 Another explanation exists, though, one less concrete, yet equally dramatic and historical . Another explanation is that the story of the Civil War was actually a hoax .
 Many of the Irish customs of death and dying are ancient holdouts, remnants of the pre-Christian Celtic society that at one time inhabited the Western Islands .
 They have been altered in constant retelling over many centuries, but they retain that element of Celtic pagan belief once so common .
 A body of Irish folklorists and scholars will explain that the leprechaun is actually Lugh of the Long Arm, the ancient Celtic god of light and the arts . The mysterious Irish fairy known as the pucha is a distortion of Epona, a Celtic horse goddess .
 As our modern technological society continues its unending march across the globe, traditional folk belief and custom is crushed beneath its merciless tread . Traditional folk belief, custom and tradition is crushed under the merciless tread of modern technology .
 Legend of the death omen still lingers in rural areas of western Ireland . The banshee is most famously known as the banshee, most famously in Ireland .
 Even in the face of the recent technological and economic boom Ireland is experiencing, the idea persists in some quarters that a supernatural being lingers in the very shadow of death .
 Bean means woman and Si designates the fairies; quite simply, a Bean si or banshee is a fairy woman . A Bean si is a banshee, or a banhee .
 The Tir na nOg, or “Land of Eternal Youth” is a place few mortals have visited, and from which even fewer have returned . As such she is making her abode in the Tir na og, making her a member of the world's most famous
 The banshee, while sharing some characteristics with spirits, is not a ghost . "The banshee" is not "a ghost"
 She never lived as a mortal human, but exists as a creature with her own purpose . She was born as a child, but she was never a child . She is now a woman with a unique purpose .
 Traditionally the banshee has held a particular function — to chaoin over the recent or impending death in a noble Gaelic family . The banshee holds a function over the death of a noble family .
 "In this mode, the banshee is not menacing, but rather a sympathetic otherworldly figure who feels sorrow and offers condolence" "The banshee" was not menacing but rather rather sympathetic otherworld figure .
 Like many of the fairy legends, the story of the banshee suggests an older origin . The banshee is believed to have been born in the U.S.
 The Celts believed that their kings and chieftains were not the owners of the land, but rather the human manifestations of it . The ancient Celts believe that the land is owned by humans, not its owners .
 As the king was responsible for the health of the land, so famine, plague, drought, or crop failure were likewise blamed on the king and his rule .
 On his inauguration, the new leader was symbolically wed to the local goddesses of sovereignty in any number of ceremonies . The new leader is symbolically married to his new government .
 His misrule would anger the goddess, causing her to punish her ‘husband’ and the land he oversaw . The goddess would punish him for his misrule .
 At the death of the leader, the goddess might manifest herself to grieve along with his human widow . The goddess may manifest herself along with the human widow of a leader .
 This theory of the banshee’s origins is further bolstered by the legend that accompanies the epic Battle of Clontarf in 1014 .
 The night before the Irish king Brian Boru was to give battle to the Danes, he was visited by the goddess Aoibheall . The goddess was native to the region around County Clare, County Clare .
 Aoibheall foretold the death of the king and announced his son Donnchad as successor to him . The king's death was announced by his son and his successor Donnchade as successor .
 This would seem a likely origin of the banshee as a female being who follows royal Irishmen . The banshee is believed to have been the most powerful female being in Ireland .
 This term may refer back to the Celtic war goddess Badb, again demonstrating the banshee’s pagan origins .
 Not every death is heralded by the fearful wailing of the banshee, thankfully enough . The banshee's death is not the first death to be heralded .
 Folklore tells us that the banshee is attached only to very important families, usually of Gaelic stock . Folklore says that the banhee is only attached to very powerful families .
 Stories of the banshee come not only from Gaelic families, but from Saxon septs with distinctly Saxon surnames . The banshee is said to have come from a number of Saxon families .
 The Potterton family, the Cartwright family, and even the English family all have a keening woman . While it is not surprising to find a banshee legend attached to the O’Keefes, Aherns, Clancys and Hegartys .
 In fact, the most oft-told tales of the banshee come from Anglo-Irish family traditions .
 One of the more famous examples is also an example of a variation on the traditional banshee legend . The more famous example is also a variation of the traditional banhee legend.

 She then began walking to one of the many cliffs that line the Ouachita River, where she plunged to her death moments later .

 In the mid 16th century the tulip was introduced to Europe from the Ottoman Empire . The tulip is the most popular tulip flower in the world, and was introduced in 16th Century .
 After decades of study by botanists, it has been found that tulips thrived best in the Netherlands .
 The tulip trade thrived to the point that be the 1630’ s people were even making careers out of growing, breeding, and selling tulips .
 The flower became a status symbol among well-to-do and wealthy Dutch as breeders created tougher and more beautiful species of flowers .
 Eventually the tulip became more than just a mere flower, but a source of wealth and prestige for the Dutch upper class . The tulip is now considered a symbol of the Dutch aristocracy .
 In the 1630’ s the tulip became a securities instrument as . i nvestors . pumped their money into tulip growing and breeding . The tulip was a popular investment instrument in 1630s .
 The profits made in the tulip business attracted more and more investors who sought to get rich quite . The profits were made from tulip profits .

 In one transaction 12 acres of land was traded for a single Semper Augustus bulb . The bulb was sold for 12 years ago .
 Some people risked all of their savings to buy just one rare bulb, which was hoped to bring fortune and wealth . The price of the rare bulb continued to rise and rise .
 By the height of tulip mania, the average tulip bulb was selling for 5,000 guilders per bulb . The tulip bulbs were sold at the peak of mania in the 1930s .
 By the spring of 1637, the price of tulips became so inflated that the vast majority of Dutch buyers and investors could not afford to buy a single bulb .
 Tulip auctions ceased to sell their bulbs as buyers could not come up with the money to cover the inflated costs . Tulip bulbs were auctioned off as buyers were unable to pay for the bulbs .
 Between February and April of 1637, tulip prices crashed to l/20th their price at the height of the mania . tulip mania was the peak of tulipmania in 1637 .
 Investors lost everything as their precious bulbs became instantly worthless . The bulbs were instantly worthless.
 Many people had their entire wealth wiped out in what would become one of the first economic bubbles in history . The bubble would be the first of its kind in the world .
 Those who burrowed money to invest were doubly screwed, as they now owed thousands of guilders to creditors and lenders .
 By summer of 1637, the price of tulips dropped to the point that hundreds of bulbs could be bought for a single guilder . Hundreds of bulbs were bought for just one guilder in summer 1637 .
 At an international conference he stood up and claimed to have found a man who had a first class maths degree and an IQ of 126, but his skull did not contain a brain .
 If you placed a torch against one side of his skull then the whole head would glow like a light bulb, says Lorber . Lorber: "You placed a light on the side of your skull then you could see it glow."
 To prove his point, Lorber produced Xrays that showed a black void where the man’s brain should have been .
 The man, named Roger, had 95 per cent of his brain missing but was normal in all other respects . The man was named Roger but was 'normal' according to Lorber .
 Lorber's discovery was an adult example of the neurological disorder known as hydranencephalus . Lorber had discovered the disorder in an adult .
 At an early stage the skull fills with fluid so that the brain never develops . This is normally associated with birth defects, such as spina bifida, and means that at early stages the skull fill with fluid . This means the brain does not develop and the brain doesn't develop
 Hydranencephalus is a severe condition and usually renders infants severely disabled, assuming that they can survive at all . It is a condition that usually renders babies severely disabled .
 The case of Roger, the man with no brain, seemed to fly against conventional brain science . Lorber came under suspicion from his colleagues after his announcement .
 Lorber himself used the example of Roger to ask a fundamental question . Lorber: "Roger is not Roger. Roger is Roger. He is Roger." Lorber says, "Roger has been Roger for more than 30 years" Lorber asks: 'Roger is Roger'
 Others see Roger as proof that the mind and brain are in fact two separate entities . Others have been less reticent and see him as proof of the brain and mind being separate .
 Lorber’s work has been taken as proof that human consciousness can survive death . Many Christian groups and proponents of an independent ‘soul’ have taken Lorber's work to be proof that .
 By 1982 Lorber had found at least two others with hydranencephalus, and at last count he believed he had traced as many as 50 . By last count, Lorber believed he'd traced up to 50 of the patients .
 He died in 1996 and the neurological community’s interest in adult hydranencephalus died with him .
 None of the patients had ever even heard of Lorber’s research, let alone encountered an adult patient such as Roger . None of them had ever met Lorber's research, nor had ever encountered him .
 After some effort, I tracked down one of Lorber’s co-workers, who wishes to remain anonymous . Lorber's co-worker says he is proud of his work ethic, but he is not surprised .
 All this suggests that the case of Roger may not be as straightforward as it first appears and maybe even places doubt on the idea that an adult can live without a brain . Roger may have been able to live with a brain without having a brain, according to his doctors .
 Sharon Parker, a hydranencephalic woman from the north of England, was discovered to have nearly 90 per cent of her brain missing in 2002 .
 Early tests suggest that her brain keeps working by using a complex and little understood form of rerouting and jobsharing between those few parts of her brain that still remain intact .
 Sharon Parker is at last tangible proof that Lorber’s work was not complete fiction, as some have suggested . Sharon Parker was Sharon Parker, the author of Lorber's first novel, in the 1960s .
 Lorber's claim that there were a great many people walking around with next to no brain inside their skulls could well be true . In fact, Lorber’s claim that many people are walking around without a brain in their skulls .
 Be careful the next time you call somebody a ‘pea-brain’ you might just be telling the truth .

 It's difficult to associate a cemetery with a place of happiness and celebration when all you think about is how much you miss the person when you visit their grave . Cemeteries are no longer associated with happiness or celebration .
 Stan loan Patra$, from the small village of Sapanta in Romania, has turned cemeteries into joyful places to celebrate the lives of loved ones . Stan Patra$ is a man named Stan . Stan .
 Patra Patra founded the aptly-named Cimitirul Vesel, or Merry Cemetery, in the 1930s . Patra^ founded the appropriately-named cemetery .
 He began creating colorful, cross-shaped tombstones and writing epitaphs for village people who had passed away .
 Each tombstone is painted with a base of a signature blue color, and then detailed with brightly-colored lines and patterns . The tombstones are painted in blue, then detailed in patterns .
 The epitaphs are silly but meaningful lyrical poems that describe something significant about the person's life . They are meant to be humorous but meaningful poems .
 Along with the poems, paintings of scenes from the person's life are included as well, usually having to do with their occupation .
 The epitaphs and paintings are often whimsical, and sometimes even satirical, and often satirical .
 Patra$ himself passed away in 1977, and he is now buried in the Merry Cemetery with a colorful tomb .
 The Merry Cemetery has its roots in the local Dacian culture, which views death as an adventure, a joyful passing to the next life . The cemetery is located in the city of Dacia, Romania .
 "It's quite the contrast to our Western view that death is a tragedy that should be grieved and mourned," she says . It's quite a contrast to Western view of death being a tragedy, she adds .
 It's pretty refreshing to see a place that's usually so weighed down with grief become so light-hearted and celebratory . It's definitely not something most of us are used to, but it's not something we're used to .

 Tomb robbers a dying breed in Italy following crackdowns . Tombaroli raiders are no longer easy for the ‘tombaroli,’ Italy’s tomb raiders .
 Pietro Casasanta had no Indiana Jones-type escapes from angry natives or booby-trapped temples . Pietro Cascasanta was born in Italy in 17th century .
 He worked undisturbed in daylight with a bulldozer . He posed as a construction worker to become one of Italy’s most successful plunderers of archaeological treasures .
 When he wasn’t in prison, the convicted looter operated for decades in this countryside area outside Rome . He says lax surveillance allowed him to dig into ancient Roman villas and unearth statues, pottery and other artifacts . He then sold for millions of dollars on the illegal
 Casasanta, 69, was the prince of the tombaroli, as the looters are known in Italy . Some of his finds are priceless, and some of them are priceless .
 Police and prosecutors believe they are beginning to see results in efforts to combat the traffic of stolen or illegally excavated antiquities . They say the antiquities made their way to the world’s top museums and collectors .
 Giovanni Nistri, who heads the art squad with the Carabinieri, Italy’s paramilitary police, said that in 2006 his unit discovered fewer than 40 illegal digs .
 Increased monitoring of archaeological sites has landed diggers like Casasanta in jail . Increased monitoring has landed archaeologists in jail in recent years .
 Pietro Casasanta stands near the ruins of a Roman palace in Anguillara Sabazia, near Rome, last month .
 Italy has been pressuring some U.S. museums to return artifacts . Italy has also pressured some museums in the United States to return them .
 Marion True, aad art dealer Robert Hecht, are accused of knowingly receiving dozens of archaeological treasures that were smuggled out despite laws making all antiquities found in Italy state property .
 Negotiations between Italy and the Getty have so far failed to yield a deal . Italy and Getty have been unable to agree a deal on the Getty .
 Italy’s efforts have scared museums and the international art market into following stricter guidelines for acquisitions, Nistri says .
 Over the last years the crackdown has been felt on the legal art market, experts say . Buyers are concentrating more on objects coming from private collections or other legitimate sources .
 Zilverberg said dealers and museums are learning their lesson . But he said authorities didn't monitor what was happening in their own archaeological backyards .
 When Casasanta started out in the 1950s he would sell his finds at tiny stalls that openly dealt in antiquities on the streets of Rome . He would sell antiquities in the tiny stalls on the city's streets, selling them at little shops .
 Too poor to get an education, he used part of his earnings to buy secondhand books about archaeology, fueling his growing passion . He used to be too poor to study archaeology .
 Casasanta first got interested in ancient relics at 14, when he was a teenager . The son of a mason, he was visiting the countryside around Anguillara, an area rich in Etruscan and Roman remains .
 Pottery and sculpture brought up by the plow caught his attention in the fields . Pottery, sculpture and sculptures were brought up from the fields by the field .
 His targets were usually Roman villas, on which he worked with a bulldozer and a couple of helpers . His target was a Roman villa, with the help of a few helpers .
 At such sites he uncovered statues of emperors and gods, as well as what he considers his greatest find — a 4th-century-B.C. ivory mask representing the Greek divinity Apollo . The mask is believed to have been found in the 4th Century-Century
 Casasanta unearthed the statue in 1994 and sold it to a Germany-based dealer . He says he was cheated and received less than a tenth of the $10 million agreed upon . He unearthed it in 1994, but says he received less of the money .
 Italian police recovered the mask in London in 2003 . In revenge, he reported the dealer to authorities and Italian police ultimately recovered it .

 John Chapman decided to leave his family’s farm in Massachusetts and go west to seek his fortune on the frontier in 1797 . Chapman was a 23-year-old man who left his family's farm in September of 1797 to seek fortune .
 Chapman thought that he could make money by starting an apple tree nursery in western Pennsylvania . He wanted to sell seedling trees to other settlers as they arrived in search of cheap land . The nursery was established in 1880 .
 John Chapman was pictured in Harper’s New Monthly Magazine in November of 1871 . Chapman was the subject of a series of articles in Harper's New Monthly magazine . Chapman died in 1871 at the age of 92 .
 The artist portrayed him wearing a belted robe that does not match any eyewitness descriptions of Chapman ‘s usual dress’ Chapman was killed in 1993 .
 Chapman knew that almost every farmer who settled in the west would plant a large orchard in order to produce alcoholic apple cider . Chapman knew about the orchard's orchard and said it would be used to make cider .
 Americans did not eat many apples in Chapman's day, but they liked to drink cider with every meal . Americans didn't like to eat apples in their day .
 Even small children drank hard cider with breakfast, dinner, and supper . Hard cider was thought to be the healthiest beverage available .
 Unlike creek water and unpasteurized milk, cider drunk in moderation seldom made anyone sick . Cider drunk with a moderate dose of cider in moderation rarely makes people sick .
 Alcohol-free “sweet” cider was more wholesome than hard cider . Without refrigeration refrigeration it fermented after a few days in the barrel .
 Chapman calculated he could sell thousands of young apple trees on the frontier . Every settler would want to plant at least fifty fruit trees to provide his family with a year’s supply of cider . Chapman calculated that he would sell thousands .
 Most settlers would plant even more trees— perhaps two hundred -- to produce extra cider for sale . Most would plant more trees to produce more cider .
 Chapman knew settlers could start their orchards from seed, but he reasoned that most would prefer the faster and easier method of planting young trees . Chapman: "Most would prefer to plant young trees from seed"
 Two-year-old seedlings sold for six cents each in western Pennsylvania . He hoped that he could sell thousands of two-year old seedlings .
 Chapman visited a Massachusetts cider mill during the fall apple harvest . He visited a cider mill in the state to learn how to make cider .
 He collected all of the apple seeds that he wanted, free of charge, by picking through the waste pulp dumped by the mill . The waste pulp was dumped by an apple mill .
 Chapman began hiking west in late October of 1797 . With a big sack of apple seeds among the provisions in his backpack, he began hiking .
 The weather was mild during the first weeks of his hike, but in mid-November, Chapman encountered a blizzard . Chapman encountered the blizzard after passing the last settlements of the Susquehanna River valley .
 He was hiking along a mountain ridge in central Pennsylvania, days away from the nearest cabins, when the storm hit . The storm hit the ridge days before the nearest cabinins were hit .
 Chapman built a fire and a leanto shelter, and then he relaxed on a bed of boughs while the wind howled around him for days . Chapman built fire and shelter, then he relaxed on a . bed of a bed on a bough while the winds howled
 When the weather cleared, Chapman discovered that it was impossible for him to resume his journey because of massive snowdrifts that buried the trail . Chapman was an exceptionally calm and reflective young man .
 He returned to his fire, stretched out on his bed of boughs, and gazed thoughtfully at the snowcovered beech trees that towered around him .
 He got up and used his knife to cut the beech branches into flexible wands . He then cut the branches into wands with his knife .
 He bent branches into shape of snowshoes, fastened them with strips of cloth from his jacket . He sliced the hem of his jacket into strips, bent the branches into the shape of a snowshoe .
 After a full day of tinkering, he had made a serviceable pair of snowshoes .
 He walked over the drifts for a week until he reached the future site of Warren, Pennsylvania, where a land company had opened an office in a cabin .
 The story of how he survived the blizzard became a permanent part of local folklore . The handful of settlers at Warren were so impressed by Chapman’s improvised snowshoes that the story of his survival became part of the story .
 Chapman chose a site for his tree nursery at the place where the Big Brokenstraw Creek joins the Allegheny River . Chapman chose the site six miles from Warren, Pennsylvania, about six miles away .
 With an axe as his only tool, he killed the big trees on three acres of land by “girdling’s” each tree, slicing off the bark in a circle clear around each trunk .
 He built a rough fence of logs and brush to keep deer out of his clearing . He then built a fence to keep the deer out .
 In the spring he planted apple seeds on the fenced land . three acres of ground for a nursery. three acres .
 Chapman probably did most of his work of site selection, tree girdling, and fence-building in the fall and winter months . Chapman is known for his work in the early 1900s and early 1800s .
 By spring he would have multiple clearings ready for planting, and he could travel swiftly by canoe from one clearing to another, to get all of his seeds into the ground .
 Chapman’s younger brother, Lawrence, became interested in his enterprise and for a while accompanied Chapman on his nursery-planting expeditions into the wilderness . The elder brother became interested and became involved in his business .
 Eventually Lawrence grew tired of camping in the forest, and he abandoned the project . Lawrence eventually grew tired and abandoned his camping project .
 John Chapman was so committed to tree planting that people on the frontier began to call him “Johnny Appleseed’s” nickname . Chapman remained committed to planting trees, but people began calling him ‘Johnny Appleeed”
 He was an amiable man who did a lot of talking whenever he got the chance, but he did not mind solitude . He was also known for his work in the field of politics, but not for his quietness .
 When not doing the strenuous work of clearing land for nurseries, he enjoyed loafing beside his fire, observing nature or reading .
 By 1802 Chapman had planted nurseries at many scattered locations along the Allegheny and Ohio Rivers and their tributaries . Chapman was earning steady income from the sale of seedling trees to new settlers .
 He had become good at guessing where it* „,” “a i;uu, were treacherously false friends . He had learned to guess where the friends were .
 Chapman was able to travel freely from one Indian town to another in Ohio during the War of 1812 . Chapman spoke Algonquian dialects fluently and traveled freely during the war .
 Chapman's habit of traveling with few possessions may have been a practical solution to the challenges of frontier life, but it also had a philosophical basis . Chapman’s habit of going without possessions may be sensible and practical .
 He was profoundly influenced by the writings of Emanuel Swedenborg, a Swedish scientist who became a Christian mystic . He was influenced by Swedenborg's writings, which he was inspired by .
 Chapman agreed with Swedenborg, and also with the ancient Greek philosopher Plato, that attachment to material things leads to unhappiness . Chapman: Material world is imperfect reflection of ideal spiritual world .
 When he visited a frontier cabin and was invited to sleep in a bed, he would politely decline and instead lie down on the floor by the fire .
 He refused to harm any animal, and lived on a vegetarian diet that included wild nuts, roots, and herbs . The author refused to kill any animal .
 Swedenborg’s doctrine that the Bible should not be taken literally, but should instead be read as a metaphoric guide to Platonic philosophy . He told one settler that, when he had been trapped by ice on an island in the Ohio River for several months, Swedenborg
 When Chapman discoursourshed on such topics, people on the Ohio frontier listened politely, but they seldom made much effort to figure out what he was talking about . Chapman: "People on the frontier listen politely"
 According to folklore, Chapman was extremely religious, but his ideas about heaven and hell were unconventional . Chapman got into many baffling, complicated debates with / fundamentalist preachers .
 Despite his peculiarities, Chapman was a well-respected man on the frontier . Chapman was known for his eccentricities, he was a respected leader in frontier .
 "Everybody knew that he was a successful businessman with a good education," says CNN.com's John Sutter . "He was a good businessman," he says .
 He habitually went barefoot and dressed in threadbare clothing and oddlooking homemade hats . He always looked clean and tidy, with his long hair neatly parted in the middle .
 Chapman's agents had standing orders to sell seedlings on credit to anyone who could not pay cash . Chapman never made the slightest effort to collect a debt so payment was effectively voluntary .
 Chapman also made gifts of cash to needy people . Chapman once handed fifty dollars to one astonished widow . Chapman also gave money to one widow .
 To spare horses from slaughter, he bought them and arranged for them to be put out to pasture . He bought them to spare them from slaughter and put them in pasture .
 Chapman became a hero to many frontier settlers during the War of 1812 . He gave white settlers diverse varieties of bitter, inedible crabapples .
 He was not interested in raising trees that yielded sweet, edible apples, because such trees cannot normally be grown from seeds . Such trees have to be propagated artificially by grafting .
 Chapman disliked grafting because he considered it unnatural . He knew that his customers would be perfectly satisfied with bitter crabapples because they made good cider . Chapman knew his customers were perfectly satisfied because of the cider .
 Chapman’s seedling trees flourished, but few new settlers moved into the area around Warren . Chapman's seedling tree grew, but the area remained largely empty . The area is now a ghost town .
 Chapman decided that he had chosen the wrong place to plant his nursery, since there were not enough customers . Chapman decided to plant a nursery in the city, but there were too many customers .
 Chapman decided to plant nurseries in western Pennsylvania and eastern Ohio . He wanted to be sure he would attract plenty of customers for his seedlings .
 Chapman spent the ensuing years planting tree nurseries at various locations in western Pennsylvania and eastern Ohio . Chapman spent most of the time planting nurseries in Ohio and Pennsylvania .
 Every fall he would collect bushels of apple seeds from eastern cider mills . The seeds were collected from the cider mills in eastern cider towns .
 He would carry seeds to Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, where he would load them into a dugout canoe . The seeds would be loaded into the canoe .

 He did not remain long at any of his nurseries but hired local settlers to serve as his agents . Local settlers tended to the profitable seedlings and sold them on commission .
 Chapman spent months every year traveling . up wilderness tributaries of the Ohio River in dugout canoes . Chapman’s increasing prosperity, he continued to lead an itinerant life .
 His growing attachment to his primitive way of life left him with little use for the hoard of cash that he was accumulating . He was forced to live on a primitive lifestyle that left him unable to find a way to survive .
 Chapman usually carried no money, keeping his cash hidden at various locations in the woods . Since outlaw gangs occasionally preyed on river traffic, Chapman kept cash hidden .
 He carried nothing that anybody might be tempted to steal— no gun, no traps, no coat, no shoes— nothing that he valued except for his books and his apple seeds, which nobody else wanted . "Nobody else wanted. Nobody else wanted."
 Chapman’s lack of tangible possessions kept him safe from outlaws and smoothed his relations with Indians . Chapman's lack of physical possessions helped keep him safe and helped him stay alive . Chapman was killed in 1877 by a group of Indians .

 Scientists say popcorn kernels resist popping into puffy white globes . Scientists say they now know why some popcorn kernels don't pop up . Scientists also say they know why popcorn doesn't pop quickly enough .
 It's long been known that popcorn kernels must have a precise moisture level in their starchy center -about 1 5 percent -to explode . The moisture in the center of popcorn kernels is about 1 5% .
 Unpopped kernels, it turns out, have leaky hulls that prevent moisture pressure buildup needed for them to pop . Most kernels lack the optimal hull structure that allows them to explode .
 The findings may help popcorn breeders select the best varieties or create new ones with superior hulls .
 In the varieties popped, the percentage of unpopped kernels ranged from 4 percent in premium brands to 47 percent in the cheaper ones .
 1 7 billion quarts of popcorn are sold each year in the United States . The findings could be good news for people who savor popcorn .

 The astragalus, or anklebone, is the most distinctive element of the artiodactyl skeleton . It has a double-pulley shape, with clearly defined grooves at the top and bottom of the bone .
 The shape gives artiodactyls greater spring and flexibility than the singlepulley form found in other quadrupeds . The shape of artiodactsyls gives them greater spring, flexibility .

 By adapting to water, early whales gained access to an environment closed to most other mammals, rich in food and shelter, and short on competitors and predators . The environment was perfect conditions for an evolutionary explosion .

 Hind legs thickened into pistons; toes stretched and grew webbing . They resembled enormous ducks’ feet tipped with tiny hooves inherited from their ungulate ancestors . They resemble enormous ducks with little hooves .

 Nostrils slid back up snout toward the crown of the head, becoming blowholes . Nostrils slide back up the snout to become blowholes, becoming a blowhole .
 Over time, as the animals dived deeper, their eyes began to migrate from the top toward the sides of the head, the better to see laterally in the water . The animals' eyes migrate to the side of their heads as they dive deeper, the study shows .
 Whale ears grew ever more sensitive to underwater sound, aided by pads of fat that ran in channels the length of their jaws . The fat pads gathered vibrations like underwater antennae and funneled them to the middle ear . Whales ears grew increasingly sensitive to sound .
 45million-year-old whales still had to hitch themselves ashore on webbed fingers and toes, in search of fresh water to drink, a mate, or a safe place to bear their young .
 Basilosaurus, Dorudon, and their relatives never set foot on land, swimming confidently on the high seas . They even crossed the Atlantic to reach the shores of what is now Peru and the southern United States .

 The final transition from basilosaurids to modern whales began 34 million years ago . It was during the sudden phase of cooling climate that ended the Eocene epoch . The transition began during a sudden period of cooling .

 Thermoluminescence has dated the pottery to 2,500 years ago . The pottery is in line with Cambyses' time .

 She chased the young Zuni hunters, killing a few of the young tribesmen . She chased them, killing some of the hunters . The young tribesman was killed by the woman .
 Later, Hoya flew home with two bear cubs and at dawn he placed them on the roof . Hoya placed the cubs on the top of his roof .
 When villagers discovered the bears on Kia's roof, they knew that Hoya was still alive . The bears were found on the roof of Kia, a car owned by Hoya's family .
 Hoya decided to fly to his beloved grandmother's home near Rainbow Cave to seek her wisdom about a new plan of his own . Hoya's grandmother is a member of the Rainbow Cave family . He decided to ask her advice about his new plan .
 She helped him paint a bird cage with many colours and they filled it with birds of matching colours . The cage was filled with matching colours and filled with birds .
 Back to Zuni village he flew, carrying the cage, which he placed in the centre of the plaza . He placed the cage in the Zuni plaza .
 From that moment on, all of the happy, dancing Zuni tribe accepted Hoya and his gifts .
 His wife they called Mother, and they called him Father of their tribe for many contented years . The tribe was contented with his wife and his wife .
 Debate over Zwarte Piet has raged in the Netherlands in recent years . Black Pete is usually portrayed by white people in blackface makeup, with thick red lips and a frizzy Afro hairstyle .
 St. Nicholas arrived by steamboat from Spain in November, accompanied by a flotilla of boats packed with Black Petes .
 Amsterdam has begun discussing possible solutions, including using different colors of face paint for Pete, or smudging his cheeks with soot . Amsterdam has also discussed possible solutions to the problem .
 The issue is sometimes linked to ongoing tensions between native Dutch and immigrants . The issue has been debated for more than a decade .
 Opponents often are told to embrace the tradition, a remark that's especially galling for secondor third-generation Dutch people . Opponents say they should embrace tradition, but that's not true .
 Two white female Dutch celebrities who oppose the Petes and have married black men have been the target of ugly sexual insults . Victoria's Secret mode Doutzen Kroes and singer Anouk have also been the targets of the insults .
